A teen-aged girl gets the horse of her dreams and is trained by an ex-Jockey to participate in London's Grand National Steeplechase. In post- colonial London, she faces racism, sexism, and D-day celebrations – the intersection of class, racial, and gender lines are limned in this quite readable novel.

Leland follows the story of Leland P. Fitzgerald (Ryan Gosling), a disaffected teenager who has apparently murdered a severely retarded peer, the brother of his would-be lover and a local high-school teacher. I have always loved The Muppets. Though most children's entertainment then wasn't that likable, The Muppet's was. The Muppet's were a weird mix of handmade puppets that looked like your grandparents hand stitched them, and wild humour that kids found hysterical. A River Runs Through It is based on the true story of two fly fishing brothers, Norman and Paul, (Brad Pitt and Craig Sheffer) whose Reverend father (Tom Skerritt) tries to teach them life’s lessons by way of Fly Fishing. This is a fine musical with a timeless score by one of my favorite composers (Gershwin) and a nice 'Parisien' atmosphere which gives the Bostonians the inspiration to sing and dance their way to happiness. Marisa Monte gives life to the emotional 'But Not For Me' and the 'Concert Romantique' and 'Le Moribond' songs bring the audience to an emotional uplifting frenzy, celebrating the blessings of love.

Okay. Here's the thing. I've read through the comments of other viewers --- some trashing the film and some saying it's the funniest, most enjoyable work of kubrick ever --- and I really don't know which group I should round out. I'll just warn from the beginning that I leaned toward the former collective, and fans of kubrick's earlier, denser works are unlikely to find this one up to snuff.
